description: Development of concepts about the operation of the mammalian cardiovascular system as conceived in the years 198 (by Galenus), 1628 (by Harvey), and 1998 (at Penn by A. Noordergraaf).
name: HEMODYNAMICS

values.comments:
This course focuses on the development of concepts about the operation of the
mammalian cardiovascular system as conceived in the years 198 (by Galenus), 1628 (by
Harvey), and 1998 (at Penn by A. Noordergraaf).
Students “[expected] a lot out of this course in terms of content,” stating that it
had “the potential to be a very interesting course.” Almost all students, however, were
disappointed with the course, describing it as “very unorganized,” with the homework
and assignments being “irrelevant to the main ideas of the course.” The course topics
were “repeated excessively and did not have much breadth.”
Students criticized Professor Noordergraaf’s poor structuring of the course;
several students noted that they “learned nothing,” except for his opinion that “CPR
doesn’t work.” Consequently, the TA was left to organize the class, and one student
wrote that he “deserves special recognition.”
Students did not comment on the difficulty of this course. One respondent
highlighted a project involving a computer model as interesting, but that the “TA was not
helpful in giving [them] the necessary tools to complete the project.” This course was not
recommended for non-majors.
